figures_in_report.label: fig:parzen-errors-1
figures_in_report.caption:
In red: MSE between the mixture 1 pdf and its PW estimate\\
In blue: ValNLL between PW estimate and the sampled points;\\
while varying the window size $h_1$ and the number of sampled points for each gaussian.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} The MSE surface in $h_1$ is clearly non-linear: it falls to an optimum and rises again on both sides.\\
The bandwidth that minimizes ValNLL is smaller than the one minimizing grid-MSE (a shift of $\Delta h_1=3.014$), so ValNLL selection is consistently more undersmoothed on this sweep.\\
On the MSE-optimal slice, increasing samples per Gaussian mainly reduces error by shrinking variance, but with diminishing returns.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Best-MSE at $(n=174,h_1=5.126)$ with MSE=1.46e-05; log(MSE) vs $h_1$ slopes: under $b=-0.965$, over $b=0.19$; sample-size elasticity at $h_1^*$: $\alpha=-0.889$ in MSE $\propto n^\alpha$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:parzen-errors-2
figures_in_report.caption:
In red: MSE between the mixture 2 pdf and its PW estimate\\
In blue: ValNLL between PW estimate and the sampled points;\\
while varying the window size $h_1$ and the number of sampled points for each gaussian.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} The MSE curve forms a pronounced U-shape in $h_1$, rather than changing smoothly or linearly.\\
The bandwidth that minimizes ValNLL is smaller than the one minimizing grid-MSE (a shift of $\Delta h_1=2.344$), so ValNLL selection is consistently more undersmoothed on this sweep.\\
Varying the per-component sample count helps, but the bandwidth choice dominates the error once you move away from $h_1^*$.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Best-MSE at $(n=193,h_1=5.536)$ with MSE=1.89e-05; log(MSE) vs $h_1$ slopes: under $b=-0.823$, over $b=0.123$; sample-size elasticity at $h_1^*$: $\alpha=-0.821$ in MSE $\propto n^\alpha$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:parzen-errors-3
figures_in_report.caption:
In red: MSE between the mixture 3 pdf and its PW estimate\\
In blue: ValNLL between PW estimate and the sampled points;\\
while varying the window size $h_1$ and the number of sampled points for each gaussian.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} What stands out is the asymmetry around the optimum: the under-smoothed side climbs much faster than the over-smoothed side.\\
The bandwidth that minimizes ValNLL is smaller than the one minimizing grid-MSE (a shift of $\Delta h_1=3.737$), so ValNLL selection is consistently more undersmoothed on this sweep.\\
The bandwidth mismatch is not cosmetic: it changes where probability mass gets smeared and shows up directly in the error slopes.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Best-MSE at $(n=169,h_1=7.484)$ with MSE=1.71e-05; log(MSE) vs $h_1$ slopes: under $b=-0.538$, over $b=0.079$; sample-size elasticity at $h_1^*$: $\alpha=-0.438$ in MSE $\propto n^\alpha$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:parzen-overlay-1
figures_in_report.caption:
Top row: pdf mixture 1 pdf;\\
Bottom: PW estimates selected by minimizing NLL and MSE respectively.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} Comparing the two overlays, the ValNLL pick is the visibly more ‘spiky’ one, consistent with a smaller bandwidth.\\
Quantitatively, that comes from selecting a smaller $h_1$ and usually fewer samples per Gaussian under ValNLL.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} MSE-min $(n=174,h_1=5.126)$ vs ValNLL-min $(n=70,h_1=2.112)$; $\Delta n=104$, $\Delta h_1=3.014$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:parzen-overlay-2
figures_in_report.caption:
Top row: pdf mixture 2 pdf;\\
Bottom: PW estimates selected by minimizing NLL and MSE respectively.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} The two selection rules disagree in a systematic direction: ValNLL chooses the tighter (more undersmoothed) KDE than MSE does.\\
Quantitatively, that comes from selecting a smaller $h_1$ and usually fewer samples per Gaussian under ValNLL.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} MSE-min $(n=193,h_1=5.536)$ vs ValNLL-min $(n=70,h_1=3.192)$; $\Delta n=123$, $\Delta h_1=2.344$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:parzen-overlay-3
figures_in_report.caption:
Top row: pdf mixture 3 pdf;\\
Bottom: PW estimates selected by minimizing NLL and MSE respectively.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} The overlay difference is mostly a bandwidth effect: the ValNLL solution keeps sharper peaks, while the MSE solution trades sharpness for shape fidelity.\\
Quantitatively, that comes from selecting a smaller $h_1$ and usually fewer samples per Gaussian under ValNLL.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} MSE-min $(n=169,h_1=7.484)$ vs ValNLL-min $(n=78,h_1=3.747)$; $\Delta n=91$, $\Delta h_1=3.737$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-error-1
figures_in_report.caption:
Top: Eval-MSE surface between mixture 1 pdf and PNN estimate over epoch × $h_1$\\
Bottom: final grid MSE (last epoch) vs $h_1$ shown as mean ± std\\
across 10 runs (PNN) and KDE for reference.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} Here the PNN does not move the MSE-optimal bandwidth away from KDE on this discrete grid, but it can change the error level at a fixed $h_1$.\\
A practical takeaway is that, at the intentionally undersmoothed point $h_1=2$, the right architecture can measurably outperform the KDE reference.\\
At $h_1=2$, deeper nets are also less variable across seeds (median std 5.4e-05 vs 9.85e-05).\\
\textbf{Evidence.} KDE $h_1^\mathrm{opt}=7$, PNN median $h_1^\mathrm{opt}=7$; At $h_1=2$, best is \texttt{MLP\_20\_sigmoid\_outSigmoid\_Aauto} with $\Delta\mathrm{MSE}=-0.000155$ (t=-4.257, p=0.002, n=10). ValNLL–MSE: $\rho=0.756$ (p=0.00071, n=16).

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-error-2
figures_in_report.caption:
Top: Eval-MSE surface between mixture 2 pdf and PNN estimate over epoch × $h_1$\\
Bottom: final grid MSE (last epoch) vs $h_1$ shown as mean ± std\\
across 10 runs (PNN) and KDE for reference.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} On this sweep the PNN’s MSE-optimal bandwidth tends to drift higher than KDE’s, suggesting it tolerates (or benefits from) more smoothing on this grid.\\
Even when $h_1$ is too small (undersmoothing), some PNN architectures can partially ‘repair’ the estimate and lower grid-MSE.\\
At $h_1=2$, deeper nets are also less variable across seeds (median std 1.84e-05 vs 0.000442).\\
\textbf{Evidence.} KDE $h_1^\mathrm{opt}=7$, PNN median $h_1^\mathrm{opt}=9.5$; At $h_1=2$, best is \texttt{MLP\_30-20\_sigmoid\_outSigmoid\_Aauto} with $\Delta\mathrm{MSE}=-7.31e-05$ (t=-13.245, p=3.3e-07, n=10). ValNLL–MSE: $\rho=0.812$ (p=0.00013, n=16).

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-error-3
figures_in_report.caption:
Top row: Eval-MSE surface between mixture 3 pdf and PNN estimate over epoch × $h_1$\\
Bottom row: final grid MSE (last epoch) vs $h_1$ shown as mean ± std\\
across 10 runs (PNN) and KDE for reference.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} On this sweep the PNN’s MSE-optimal bandwidth tends to be lower than KDE’s, hinting that learning helps in the sharper (more undersmoothed) regime on this grid.\\
The interesting part is not the optimum itself but the undersmoothed slice: the PNN can still reduce error there with a good architecture choice.\\
At $h_1=2$, deeper nets are also less variable across seeds (median std 2.56e-05 vs 0.00011).\\
\textbf{Evidence.} KDE $h_1^\mathrm{opt}=12$, PNN median $h_1^\mathrm{opt}=9.5$; At $h_1=2$, best is \texttt{MLP\_30-20\_sigmoid\_outReLU} with $\Delta\mathrm{MSE}=-9.47e-05$ (t=-13.274, p=3.2e-07, n=10). ValNLL–MSE: $\rho=0.935$ (p=1.1e-07, n=16).

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-overlay-1
figures_in_report.caption:
Best overlays for mixture 1, selected by minimizing ValNLL.\\
Top row: Parzen Window (KDE) estimate vs ground-truth mixture PDF at the same selected $h_1$.\\
Bottom row: Parzen Neural Network (PNN) estimate vs ground-truth mixture PDF.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} The ValNLL-selected PNN overlay ends up slightly better than the KDE reference at the same $h_1$, so the gain is mostly a subtle shape correction rather than a bandwidth change.\\
Notably the selected $h_1$ is at the smallest value in the sweep, so the true optimum could lie outside the grid on the sharper side.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Selected \texttt{MLP\_30-20\_sigmoid\_outSigmoid\_Aauto} at $h_1=2$ with ValNLL=3.06; grid-MSE PNN=0.000239 vs KDE=0.000331, so $\Delta\mathrm{MSE}=-9.21e-05$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-overlay-2
figures_in_report.caption:
Best overlays for mixture 2, selected by minimizing ValNLL.\\
Top row: Parzen Window (KDE) estimate vs ground-truth mixture PDF at the same selected $h_1$.\\
Bottom row: Parzen Neural Network (PNN) estimate vs ground-truth mixture PDF.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} At the $h_1$ picked by ValNLL, the PNN overlay tracks the KDE baseline closely; when it improves, it tends to be by nudging local mass rather than shifting the global smoothing level.\\
A low ValNLL is still a pointwise criterion, so small local artifacts can persist even when held-out likelihood looks good.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Selected \texttt{MLP\_30-20\_sigmoid\_outSigmoid\_Aauto} at $h_1=7$ with ValNLL=3.649; grid-MSE PNN=1.83e-05 vs KDE=1.92e-05, so $\Delta\mathrm{MSE}=-8.81e-07$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-overlay-3
figures_in_report.caption:
Best overlays for mixture 3, selected by minimizing ValNLL.\\
Top row: Parzen Window (KDE) estimate vs ground-truth mixture PDF at the same selected $h_1$.\\
Bottom row: Parzen Neural Network (PNN) estimate vs ground-truth mixture PDF.
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} This panel highlights a fairly ‘honest’ selection: ValNLL chooses an overlay whose grid-MSE stays comparable to KDE at the same bandwidth, so it is not winning by overfitting bandwidth.\\
ValNLL is computed on samples, so it can miss some global-shape defects that still matter for grid-MSE.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Selected \texttt{MLP\_30-20\_sigmoid\_outReLU} at $h_1=7$ with ValNLL=3.97; grid-MSE PNN=1.31e-05 vs KDE=1.42e-05, so $\Delta\mathrm{MSE}=-1.15e-06$.

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-boundary-1
figures_in_report.caption:
Top Row: ValNLL for mixture 1 vs $h_1 \times {\lambda}$ for every PNN architecture\\
Bottom Row: PNN overlay that minimizes ValNLL@$\lambda=0$\\
vs the PNN that minimizes ValNLL $\forall\lambda$
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} The boundary penalty behaves like a tail-regularizer: it often lowers ValNLL compared to $\lambda=0$, especially when the unconstrained fit leaks mass outside the data support.\\
However it is not monotone: across a non-trivial fraction of configurations, some $\lambda$ values actually worsen ValNLL, so selection matters.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Best vs $\lambda=0$: improves in 93.75\% with mean $\Delta$=-0.034 and best $\Delta$=-0.165; worst over $\lambda$ is $\Delta_{\max}=0.03$ (positive means worse), in 37.5\% of configs.

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-boundary-2
figures_in_report.caption:
Top Row: ValNLL for mixture 2 vs $h_1 \times {\lambda}$ for every PNN architecture\\
Bottom Row: PNN overlay that minimizes ValNLL@$\lambda=0$\\
vs the PNN that minimizes ValNLL $\forall\lambda$
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} This sweep suggests $\lambda$ is useful mainly as a tail-control knob: many settings improve relative to $\lambda=0$, but the benefit depends on the (arch,$h_1$) regime.\\
It’s also not a free win: for many (arch,$h_1$) points there exists a $\lambda$ that makes things worse than $\lambda=0$.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Best vs $\lambda=0$: improves in 62.5\% with mean $\Delta$=-0.01 and best $\Delta$=-0.041; worst over $\lambda$ is $\Delta_{\max}=0.109$ (positive means worse), in 43.75\% of configs.

figures_in_report.label: fig:pnn-boundary-3
figures_in_report.caption:
Top Row: ValNLL for mixture 3 vs $h_1 \times {\lambda}$ for every PNN architecture\\
Bottom Row: PNN overlay that minimizes ValNLL@$\lambda=0$\\
vs the PNN that minimizes ValNLL $\forall\lambda$
figures_in_report.comment:
\par\noindent\textbf{Observation.} What’s noticeable is that tuning $\lambda$ can rescue some over/under-smoothed configurations in ValNLL, even if it doesn’t radically change the best achievable score.\\
It’s also not a free win: for many (arch,$h_1$) points there exists a $\lambda$ that makes things worse than $\lambda=0$.\\
\textbf{Evidence.} Best vs $\lambda=0$: improves in 81.25\% with mean $\Delta$=-0.006 and best $\Delta$=-0.026; worst over $\lambda$ is $\Delta_{\max}=0.149$ (positive means worse), in 68.75\% of configs.

latex_addenda_by_label.fig:parzen-errors-1: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} From the sweep in \texttt{logs/pw_errors_mixture1.csv}, the global minimizers are $\arg\min_{(n,h_1)}\mathrm{MSE}=(n=174,\ h_1=5.126)$ with $\mathrm{MSE}=1.46e-05$, and $\arg\min_{(n,h_1)}\mathrm{ValNLL}=(n=70,\ h_1=2.112)$ with $\mathrm{ValNLL}=2.262$. Fitting $\log\mathrm{MSE}(h_1)=a+bh_1$ on the lower-bandwidth side ($h_1<h_1^*$) gives $b=-0.965$ ($R^2=0.952$), whereas on the oversmoothed side ($h_1>h_1^*$) it gives $b=0.19$ ($R^2=0.938$), quantifying the steeper rise under undersmoothing. At $h_1=h_1^*$, a log--log fit $\log\mathrm{MSE}=c+\alpha\log n$ yields $\alpha=-0.889$ ($R^2=0.515$), i.e. $\mathrm{MSE}\propto n^{-0.889}$ on this slice.
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:parzen-errors-2: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} From the sweep in \texttt{logs/pw_errors_mixture2.csv}, the global minimizers are $\arg\min_{(n,h_1)}\mathrm{MSE}=(n=193,\ h_1=5.536)$ with $\mathrm{MSE}=1.89e-05$, and $\arg\min_{(n,h_1)}\mathrm{ValNLL}=(n=70,\ h_1=3.192)$ with $\mathrm{ValNLL}=3.327$. Fitting $\log\mathrm{MSE}(h_1)=a+bh_1$ on the lower-bandwidth side ($h_1<h_1^*$) gives $b=-0.823$ ($R^2=0.958$), whereas on the oversmoothed side ($h_1>h_1^*$) it gives $b=0.123$ ($R^2=0.94$), quantifying the steeper rise under undersmoothing. At $h_1=h_1^*$, a log--log fit $\log\mathrm{MSE}=c+\alpha\log n$ yields $\alpha=-0.821$ ($R^2=0.749$), i.e. $\mathrm{MSE}\propto n^{-0.821}$ on this slice.
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:parzen-errors-3: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} From the sweep in \texttt{logs/pw_errors_mixture3.csv}, the global minimizers are $\arg\min_{(n,h_1)}\mathrm{MSE}=(n=169,\ h_1=7.484)$ with $\mathrm{MSE}=1.71e-05$, and $\arg\min_{(n,h_1)}\mathrm{ValNLL}=(n=78,\ h_1=3.747)$ with $\mathrm{ValNLL}=3.763$. Fitting $\log\mathrm{MSE}(h_1)=a+bh_1$ on the lower-bandwidth side ($h_1<h_1^*$) gives $b=-0.538$ ($R^2=0.898$), whereas on the oversmoothed side ($h_1>h_1^*$) it gives $b=0.079$ ($R^2=0.983$), quantifying the steeper rise under undersmoothing. At $h_1=h_1^*$, a log--log fit $\log\mathrm{MSE}=c+\alpha\log n$ yields $\alpha=-0.438$ ($R^2=0.528$), i.e. $\mathrm{MSE}\propto n^{-0.438}$ on this slice.
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:parzen-overlay-1: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} The configuration selected by minimizing grid MSE uses $n=174$ and $h_1=5.126$ (grid $\mathrm{MSE}=1.46e-05$), while the ValNLL-minimizer uses $n=70$ and $h_1=2.112$ (ValNLL $=2.262$). In particular, $n_{\mathrm{MSE}}-n_{\mathrm{ValNLL}}=104$ and $h_{1,\mathrm{MSE}}-h_{1,\mathrm{ValNLL}}=3.014$.
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:parzen-overlay-2: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} The configuration selected by minimizing grid MSE uses $n=193$ and $h_1=5.536$ (grid $\mathrm{MSE}=1.89e-05$), while the ValNLL-minimizer uses $n=70$ and $h_1=3.192$ (ValNLL $=3.327$). In particular, $n_{\mathrm{MSE}}-n_{\mathrm{ValNLL}}=123$ and $h_{1,\mathrm{MSE}}-h_{1,\mathrm{ValNLL}}=2.344$.
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:parzen-overlay-3: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} The configuration selected by minimizing grid MSE uses $n=169$ and $h_1=7.484$ (grid $\mathrm{MSE}=1.71e-05$), while the ValNLL-minimizer uses $n=78$ and $h_1=3.747$ (ValNLL $=3.763$). latex_addenda_by_label.fig:pnn-error-1: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} On the bandwidth grid $h_1\in\{2, 7, 12, 16\}$ from \texttt{results/sweep_results_mixture1.json}, the KDE reference attains its minimum grid-MSE at $h_1^{\mathrm{KDE}}=7$. Across PNN architectures, the median MSE-optimal bandwidth is $\mathrm{median}(h_1^{\mathrm{PNN}})=7$ on this grid. At $h_1=2$ (undersmoothed slice), the best architecture (MLP_20_sigmoid_outSigmoid_Aauto) changes grid-MSE by $\Delta=\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{MSE}_\mathrm{PNN}-\mathrm{MSE}_\mathrm{KDE}]=-0.000155$ with one-sample t-test $t=-4.257$ (p=0.002, n=10). Across all (architecture, $h_1$) points, ValNLL vs grid-MSE alignment is $\rho=0.756$ (p=0.000706, n=16).

Across PNN architectures, the median MSE-optimal bandwidth is $\mathrm{median}(h_1^{\mathrm{PNN}})=9.5$ on this grid. At $h_1=2$ (undersmoothed slice), the best architecture (MLP_30-20_sigmoid_outSigmoid_Aauto) changes grid-MSE by $\Delta=\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{MSE}_\mathrm{PNN}-\mathrm{MSE}_\mathrm{KDE}]=-7.31e-05$ with one-sample t-test $t=-13.245$ (p=3.31e-07, n=10). latex_addenda_by_label.fig:pnn-error-3: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} On the bandwidth grid $h_1\in\{2, 7, 12, 16\}$ from \texttt{results/sweep_results_mixture3.json}, the KDE reference attains its minimum grid-MSE at $h_1^{\mathrm{KDE}}=12$. Across PNN architectures, the median MSE-optimal bandwidth is $\mathrm{median}(h_1^{\mathrm{PNN}})=9.5$ on this grid. At $h_1=2$ (undersmoothed slice), the best architecture (MLP_30-20_sigmoid_outReLU) changes grid-MSE by $\Delta=\mathbb{E}[\mathrm{MSE}_\mathrm{PNN}-\mathrm{MSE}_\mathrm{KDE}]=-9.47e-05$ with one-sample t-test $t=-13.274$ (p=3.25e-07, n=10). latex_addenda_by_label.fig:pnn-boundary-1: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} Using \texttt{results/boundary_penalty_lambda_sweep_cache.csv}, across all cached (architecture,$h_1$) settings for mixture 1, the best $\lambda$ improves mean ValNLL relative to $\lambda=0$ in 93.75\% of configurations; the average change is $\mathbb{E}[\Delta]= -0.034$ and the best observed change is $\min\Delta=-0.165$ (negative = improvement).
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:pnn-boundary-2: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} Using \texttt{results/boundary_penalty_lambda_sweep_cache.csv}, across all cached (architecture,$h_1$) settings for mixture 2, the best $\lambda$ improves mean ValNLL relative to $\lambda=0$ in 62.5\% of configurations; the average change is $\mathbb{E}[\Delta]= -0.01$ and the best observed change is $\min\Delta=-0.041$ (negative = improvement).
latex_addenda_by_label.fig:pnn-boundary-3: \par\noindent\textbf{Evidence.} Using \texttt{results/boundary_penalty_lambda_sweep_cache.csv}, across all cached (architecture,$h_1$) settings for mixture 3, the best $\lambda$ improves mean ValNLL relative to $\lambda=0$ in 81.25\% of configurations; the average change is $\mathbb{E}[\Delta]= -0.006$ and the best observed change is $\min\Delta=-0.026$ (negative = improvement).
